article.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Various Bacterial Phyla Isolated from the International Space Station
article.abstract: Whole-genome sequences were generated from 96 bacterial strains of 14 species that were isolated from International Space Station surfaces during the Microbial Tracking 2 study. Continued characterization of this closed habitat's microbiome enables tracking of the spread and evolution of secondary pathogens, which is vital for astronaut health.

sections.introduction: The International Space Station (ISS) is currently the only long-term human habitat in space. Microgravity disrupts human immune function (1), and close monitoring of the ISS microbiome for increased pathogenicity is thus an ongoing critical task.
sections.methods: Accession numbers, sampling locations, and assembly details for bacterial strains isolated from the ISS
sections.results: Four species from the phylum Actinobacteria were isolated, from the genera Pseudoclavibacter, Kocuria, and Micrococcus, all of which are common in both environmental and human microbiomes (2–5).
sections.discussion: Multiple coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) were also isolated. CoNS are normal components of human skin flora (9) and are often resistant to antibiotics because of their ability to form biofilms (10); all CoNS in this report are documented opportunistic pathogens (11–15).

article.insights_summary: The draft genomes of 96 bacterial strains isolated from the International Space Station were generated. The study aims to track the spread and evolution of secondary pathogens in the ISS microbiome.
article.acknowledgments: Part of the research described was carried out at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of the California Institute of Technology under a contract with NASA.
